newsitem.title: NEW ZEALAND: NZ bill yields end sharply lower as TWI rises.
newsitem.headline: NZ bill yields end sharply lower as TWI rises.

text.p: Figures in brackets compare against previous day's close
FUTURES PHYSICAL YIELD (PCT)
90-DAY BILLS (JUN) 92.87 (PREV 92.68) 90-DAYS 7.15 (PREV 7.32)
OVERNIGHT CASH 7.05 PCT (PREV 7.05) US 5-YR 6.58 (PREV 6.56)
MCI -70 VS -85
* NZ bank bill yields close sharply down as TWI rises
* Australian rate cut boosts NZ, surprises market
* Only limited gains seen for NZ long bonds
New Zealand bank bill yields fell 17 basis points in heavy trade on Friday fuelled by a strengthening Trade-Weighted Index.
The index was initially boosted by the rise of the U.S. dollar against the yen and got a second kick by the surprise 0.5 percent Australian rate cut.
That helped the Monetary Conditions Index fall to minus 65 from minus 85 on Thursday and gave the green light for yields to fall. The MCI ended at minus 70.
The New Zealand dollar gained steeply against the Australian unit after the rate cut. TWI strength was the driving factor. It rose to 67.65 from its 67.12 close on Thursday, ending at 67.51.

"More and more people are thinking our economy is looking somewhat soft and the next big move in interest rates is going to be done. With the Aussies cutting rates, that's also helped," said one bill dealer.
Reaction in the bond market was more muted. The curve steepened but buyers are seen as still somewhat scarce.
"I would be a reluctant buyer at these levels. We'll probably see the euro issues dry up," said one bond dealer.
-- Wellington newsroom 64 4 4734 746
